[1] Catabolism of amino acids is initiated by transamination, followed by oxidative deamination and, finally, ammonia elimination via the urea cycle (Fig. 1).  [2] Northern blot analysis was performed for genes encoding enzymes involved in these steps to determine whether there is any change in gene expression in the liver-specific HNF4Î±-null mice (Fig.3). llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea and transamination are connected through the metabolic pathway of amino acid catabolism. Transamination is the initial step where amino groups from amino acids are transferred to α-ketoglutarate, leading to the production of ammonia, which is subsequently processed in the urea cycle for elimination. This highlights the role of transamination in the formation of urea as a waste product of amino acid metabolism.
